body.p:
I regret that owing to ill health, I
was unable to attend the last two meetings of
your Board; and as I shall yet for some time be
thereby prevented from going out in the evening, I
take the liberty of hereby calling your attention to a
few remarks, which I otherwise intended to place
before you verbally, & which I consider particularly
needed at this juncture, when a new election is
about to take place.

Reviewing my connection with your honorable Board
for the last two years, I regret to find that while
we have doubtless been working with the same end
in view, the policy of the majority and mine have
been diametrically opposite. Orthodoxy being our common
object, I believe that the best method of attaining it
would be by the building up of our congregation
by attracting worshippers to its shrine by every lawful
means; rather than by being guided by the fear that
by interesting our members in the synagogue services,
we might induce them to introduce the so-called
"reform" which undoubtedly has wrought so much
mischief in other congregations. I would therefore here
indicate what I consider the actual essentials for
the promotion of spiritual life in ours--One of the
most urgent needs of the moment is a competent
assistant Hazan who would command the respect
and esteem of the congregation because he could
be relied upon to fulfill conscientiously his duties
as such, and give his active attention to our

Hebrew and religious school. One at the
same time qualified to superintend a choir
which would lead congregational singing, and
thus give dignity to the service of the synagogue.
Another important consideration is the removal
of our synagogue to a location more conveniently
situated for the majority of our congregants.
In my humble opinion it appears to be no correct
argument that the most of them ride on Sabbath
our duty as leaders of an orthodox congregation, is
to discourage this habit. Nor does it seem any any
more correct one, that a few who do not ride on
that holy day, are living in the vicinity of nine-
teenth st; for a pious minority are always expected
to make willing sacrifices for the general welfare.
Neither can it be denied, against these arguments, for
non-removal, that in the several years in which our present
location has gradually become too distant for the young
and the aged, not to mention those who may not be
in the most robust health, they have had no alternative
but to ride, or absent themselves from, the house of God
if, as staunch followers of our sublime liturgy they
cannot enjoy the same spirit of devotion among
brethern of another minhag. But another momentous
point that cannot be overlooked in this connection is,
that there being no orthodox congregation centrally
located, many of our members, consulting their
convenience, are induced to attend places of worship
whose forms and innovations we are endeavoring
to keep out of our own; and that we are thus weaken-
ing orthodoxy, to the manifest advantage of "reform."

With regard to matters affecting the welfare of
Judaism in general, it is not to be lost sight of
that, occupying the highest standing among orthodox
congregations in America, we are placed in a
responsible position. Conservative congregations in
all parts of the country, in search of ledarship
out of the entanglement of "reform" naturally look
to us for such guidance. Therefore whether or not
orthodoxy in this hemisphere is to rear its head in
the near future, will depend a great deal on the
action we take in fulfilment of our duty.

This congregation has the means to make its influence
felt; and if by using a part of its finances, we
should later be unable to show as much material
wealth as at present, we would doubtless be in a
position to enjoy more spiritual prosperity.

But even from a material point of view I am
sure we would not be the losers; for whose piety
exits, voluntary offerings are readily made for the
service of the Lord; and the increased membership
which our congregation would attract by its honored
position as consistent Israelites, would bring
abundant resources to its coffers; and thus also
would God reward our good deeds. I would have
been most happy, gentlemen, if I could have hoped
to be so fortunate as to enlist your sympathy and
support for my views of our congregational requirements,
as above expressed. In that case it would have
been my duty no less than my pleasure to make
diligent use of my very humble abilities, in fulfilment

of the responsibilities of the past which, by a
very large vote, I was called to feel, two years ago.
And I hope I have succeeded in attaining your
acknowledgment of having done my work conscientiously
while, as already intimated, I trust also to receive
your approval of the policy which I think ought
to be made the basis of activity in the incoming
administrative year.

But having unfortunately had an adverse majority
against me in the past, in what I consider such
essential matters, I have much to my regret to
resign the office I now hold on your honorable Board.
It has been a struggle with me to decide where my
duty lies; for the resignation of a position so full
of honor in God's service, might unwittingly indicate
a want of appreciation of His grace in calling me to
do His work in so important a congregation.
And if I could have entertained any hope that by
perseverance I might later be able to win your
concurrence, I would yet have hesitated before
expressing my determation. But the fear that by
further debate on this and kindred subjects while
our views are in such opposite directions, the
difference between us might on the contrary, be
intensified--which is a contingency carefully to be
avoided--leads me to the decision that there is no
alternative. Respectfully yours
(signed) D and M. Piza

To the President and
Trustees of K. K. Sheerit Israel
New York.

Rev. Dr. S. Morais,
546 N. 5th St.
Philadelphia.
